summary: This is a reply memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys in support of a motion to dismiss perjury counts (Five and Six) of the superseding indictment. The defense argues the alleged perjurious statements from Maxwell's civil deposition were responses to fundamentally ambiguous questions, were literally true, and were immaterial to the defamation case in which they were made.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, accused of perjury in Counts Five and Six of the superseding indictment. Her defense team is arguing her deposition answers were not perjurious.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, signed the reply memorandum.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed on the filing.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Cohen & Gresser LLP, signed the certificate of service.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed on the filing.

persons.name: Jane Doe 3
persons.role: Plaintiff in Defamation Case / Alleged Victim
persons.context: Referred to as 'Jane Doe 3' and 'Doe 175'. She filed a defamation lawsuit against Ghislaine Maxwell based on a statement Maxwell's UK lawyer issued. She had previously filed a motion to join a CVRA action, making detailed allegations against Maxwell and others.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Named by Jane Doe 3 in her CVRA joinder motion as someone she was forced to have sex with, which he denied. Mentioned in the statement from Maxwell's UK lawyer.

persons.name: Jean Luc Brunel
persons.context: Named by Jane Doe 3 in her CVRA joinder motion as someone she was forced to have sex with.

persons.name: Ross Gow
persons.context: Sent an email to British media on January 2, 2015, containing a statement on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell denying Jane Doe 3's allegations. This statement formed the basis of the defamation lawsuit.

persons.name: Judge Marra
persons.context: The judge in the Southern District of Florida who presided over the CVRA action and denied Jane Doe 3's motion to join, striking the 'lurid details' from her filing.

persons.name: Judge Sweet
persons.context: Presided over the defamation action and issued discovery orders related to Ghislaine Maxwell's depositions.

connections.description: Jane Doe 3 sued Maxwell for defamation. Maxwell's defense team characterizes Doe's allegations as 'obvious lies' and part of a hostile civil action.
Pagliuca is one of Maxwell's defense attorneys filing this motion on her behalf.
Gow acted as a UK lawyer/representative for Maxwell, issuing a public statement on her behalf in January 2015.
Jane Doe 3 alleged in a court filing that she was forced to have sex with Alan Dershowitz, which he denied.
Jane Doe 3 alleged in a court filing that she was forced to have sex with Jean Luc Brunel.

events.title: CVRA Action Filed
events.description: Two alleged Epstein victims filed an action under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) challenging Epstein's plea agreement.

events.title: Jane Doe 3 Files Joinder Motion
events.description: Jane Doe 3 moved to join the existing CVRA action, claiming her CVRA rights were also violated. The motion contained detailed allegations against Ghislaine Maxwell and others.

events.title: Ross Gow Issues Statement for Maxwell
events.description: UK lawyer Ross Gow emailed a statement to British media on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell, calling Jane Doe 3's allegations 'untrue' and 'obvious lies'.

events.title: Court Denies Joinder, Strikes Details
events.description: Judge Marra denied Jane Doe 3's motion to join the CVRA action and struck the 'lurid details' from her filing as unnecessary and a sanction.

events.title: Defamation Lawsuit Filed
events.description: Jane Doe 3 sued Ghislaine Maxwell for defamation, based on the January 2, 2015, statement issued by Ross Gow.

events.title: Maxwell's Depositions in Defamation Case
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was deposed in the defamation lawsuit. The questions and answers from these depositions form the basis for the perjury counts (Five and Six) in her criminal indictment.

events.title: Reply Memorandum Filed
events.description: Maxwell's defense team files this reply memorandum arguing to dismiss the perjury counts, claiming the deposition questions were ambiguous and answers literally true.

keyFacts: The perjury charges against Ghislaine Maxwell (Counts Five and Six) stem from answers she gave during depositions in a civil defamation lawsuit filed against her by 'Jane Doe 3'.
The defense argues the deposition questions were 'fundamentally ambiguous' (using terms like 'scheme' and 'recruit' without definition) and therefore cannot legally support a perjury conviction.
The defense also argues Maxwell's answers were 'literally true' under the standard set by Bronston v. United States, placing the burden on the questioner to ask precise questions.
The defamation lawsuit was based on a statement issued by Maxwell's UK lawyer, Ross Gow, which called Jane Doe 3's allegations 'untrue' and 'obvious lies'.

Jane Doe 3's allegations, detailed in a 2014 motion to join a CVRA action, accused Maxwell of being a 'primary co-conspirator' with Epstein in a sex trafficking scheme and named other individuals including Alan Dershowitz and Jean Luc Brunel.
